Pub

First things first, York's Hole in the Wall has nothing to do with that ghastly Saturday night TV show, and the Petergate pub doesn't need silver lycra to draw a crowd

Michael Allard

An <em>Anchorman<em> sequel is on the horizon, and, well, it's kind of a big deal

Centurion

It seems that filmmakers are never afraid to tackle and (for want of a better word) copy exactly the same subject matter as another film made in the same year. Such is the case with Kevin Macdonald's The Eagle Of The Ninth, released later this year, in the wake of Centurion, Neil Marshall's latest offering

The Front

In his most celebrated work, Woody Allen is both an amateur and an actor playing variations on the creative persona that's still going strong after 50 years onscreen

Cemetery Junction

It seems reasonable to assume that the vast majority of Cemetery Junction's audience will choose to watch the film based solely on Ricky Gervais and Stephen Merchant's sterling comic partnership, whose reputation was cemented by the stratospheric success of The Office and Extras

Intrepid indie ecologists Stornoway

UK indie has had many past dalliances with the pastoral; most recently British Sea Power with their foliage obsession and appearance on Countryfile. But Stornoway's sound - whimsical pop-folk that suggests sun-dappled meadows and rolling dales - is backed up with professional experience in ecology (Thumbnail credit Stornoway enjoying a post-hike sing-song)

Future Sounds

If we haven't rubbed it in your face enough yet, this weekend was 'Live at Leeds'

True Sounds of Liberty

Hannah Ellis-Petersen talks to the only boys wearing drainpipes in Kabul

Paloma Faith

aloma Faith's star is soaring. Following memorable performances on 'Later... with Jools Holland' and the considerable vitriol aimed at her outrageous outfits in Heat magazine, Faith is closing her first headlining tour in London

LCD Soundsystem

The O2 is rammed full of a heady mixture of towering bald men and miniature indie kids, which shows the broad spectrum of James Murphy's appeal

The Alternative Glee Soundtrack

Here are just a few of the tracks that should have made it into the New Directions repertoire

Harriet Lowther on 'The Big Thank you Project'

Harriet Lowther is passionately thankful - for every product she has ever used

Lowenna Waters

In the up-and-coming election, there will be inevitable cuts in the funding of the Department of Culture, whichever party gets into power

Lynne Roebuck on the commercialisation of fine art

By James Bithell

Lynne Roebuck's art is "about the impressions of landscapes we carry with us"

Up and coming events

Up and Coming Events

Johnny Blue Eyes

By James Bithell

Liam O'Brien talks to Johnny Blue Eyes, creative director of the endearingly zany House of Blue Eyes

Sofia Redgrave

When reading <em>Shantaram</em> by Gregory Davis Roberts, or watching Danny Boyle's<em> Slumdog Millionaire</em>, for that matter, it is difficult to escape from the general consensus that India, and Mumbai in particular, is overcrowded, dirty and corrupt

Fashion Forward or Backward?

Tess Webb explores the technology behind fashion today (Thumbnail credit Bloggers on the front row: it seems La Wintour is the only one paying attention)

Would you let the world know your secret?

By James Bithell

Frank Warren receives hundreds of postcards expressing people's darkest moments. Camilla Apcar investigates what led him to found the PostSecret project (Thumbnail credit Frank at home, surrounded by postcards)

Dirty $exy Money

At the end of this term, a new bunch of York graduates will depart to take on the world. Liv Evans discovers how to get exactly what you want from life (Thumbnail credit What our generation hopes to achieve?)

Street Angels

By James Bithell

Who's there when a good night goes wrong? Sian Turner investigates an organisation which helps those in difficulty in York's city centre every weekend (Thumbnail credit A street angel in action)

What does your future hold?

By James Bithell

Despite scepticism surrounding the pyschic industry, it continues to grow. Charlotte Hogarth-Jones and Hannah Ellis-Petersen investigate whether it all really is smoke and mirrors

"Nobody cares whether you're male or female. It's just: can you do the job?"

By James Bithell

As one of the few institutions not subject to sexual equality legislation, Victoria Lee asks whether the Army can - or should - aim for full gender equality (Thumbnail credit Lance-Corporal Laura Hosty at the York Army Barracks)

Henry James Foy

"You're not a lad," pipes up my girlfriend for the third time that afternoon (Thumbnail credit Photo: George Lowther)

Social pariah: Charlotte Hogarth-Jones

*Sunday night, in the midst of a particularly grim production weekend*

So-called life: Liam O'Brien

I, like many others, am in the last term of my degree at York, and like many others I have amassed a grotesquely large number of friends

Seaworld by numbers

Seaworld by numbers

The Acquaintance with Poppy Babcock
